items.title: International Effort to Curb Emissions of a Climate Super Pollutant Falls Short, UN Report Reveals
items.description: Despite the efforts of more than half of all countries worldwide to curb a key climate super-pollutant, a report released this week by the United Nations Environment Programme at the U.N. climate summit shows that global methane emissions continue to climb at a troubling pace. items.title: California Is Finally Updating Its Methane Landfill Rule
items.description: California regulators voted on Thursday to update a 15-year-old rule controlling emissions of methane from municipal landfills, the second-largest source of the climate super pollutant in the state.  The effort by California’s greenhouse gas regulators to strengthen oversight and align methods to control and monitor methane emissions from landfills with the latest technological advances is […]

items.title: Gas Pipeline Proposals in Virginia Multiply Through the South—and Worry Community Activists
items.description: As plans for natural gas pipeline expansions in southwest Virginia are rapidly taking shape, proposals from two major energy firms to transport gas through the Appalachian regions of Virginia and North Carolina are fueling community concern.  Critics are disturbed by the route of the two proposed pipelines, now under review amid a surge of applications […]

items.title: One Key State Remains in Limbo on Climate and Clean Energy Policies As Several Others Retreat
items.description: Massachusetts isn’t going to gut its landmark climate law—yet. The state House of Representatives appeared this week to be speeding toward passage of H4744, a bill that would revise some of the programs and policies behind the state’s requirement to halve its emissions by 2030 relative to 1990 levels. items.title: As Seas Rise, So Do the Risks From Toxic Sites
items.description: RICHMOND, Calif.—On a sunny morning in May, Luna Angulo walked alongside a towering chain-link fence topped with razor wire on San Francisco Bay’s eastern shore. items.title: Congress Axes Biden-Era Protections That Shielded Alaskan Wetlands From Drilling
items.description: The U.S. House of Representatives voted Tuesday to strike down protections against oil drilling in some of the most diverse ecosystems and wildest lands left in North America. items.title: N.C. Office of Recovery and Resiliency So Poorly Managed That State Auditor Couldn’t Determine Full Extent of Waste

items.title: As COP30 Unfolds in the Amazon, Brazil Is Drilling for Oil Near the Great Amazon Reef System
items.description: As world leaders conclude the United Nations’ annual climate talks in Belém, Brazil— a summit meant to accelerate global action on phasing out fossil fuels—the Brazilian government is facing mounting criticism over its recent decision to authorize offshore drilling for oil near the Great Amazon Reef System.
